name: ZAYTUNA COLLEGE
mission: Zaytuna College aims to educate and prepare morally committed professional, intellectual, and spiritual leaders, who are grounded in the Islamic scholar...
programs: BA in Liberal and Islamic Studies
Center for Ethical Living and Learning (ZCELL)
theoryOfChange: By training the mind through the trivium and quadrivium alongside Islamic primary texts, the college produces leaders who can navigate modern society with moral and spiritual grounding.

evaluationSources: Accredited by WASC Senior College and University Commission (WSCUC)

zakatClaimEvidence: According to many scholars, institutions such as Zaytuna College meet the requirements for zakat eligibility. However, we have chosen to limit the zakat funds only to the total cost of education for zakat eligible students and not for any other institutional expenditures. We take this sacred trust very seriously, so if you choose to give a portion of your zakat to Zaytuna College, we will do our utmost, God willing, to ensure its most judicious and shariah compliant use. (Source: https://zaytuna.edu/ways-to-give)

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: Zaytuna College earns a moderate overall score due to its unique educational niche and strong liquidity, balanced against a program expense ratio that suggests significant overhead or administrative costs.
areas_for_improvement: program expense ratio of 56.0% is lower than industry benchmarks for direct service delivery

dimension_explanations.alignment: With an alignment score of 29/50, the college offers a medium fit for donors interested in global education and Islamic scholarship [8]. The institution is Zakat-eligible, providing a structured pathway for Muslim donors to fulfill their religious obligations through higher education [8].
dimension_explanations.impact: The college focuses on capacity building by training future leaders, though its impact score of 27/50 reflects the indirect nature of educational leadership development compared to direct humanitarian aid [1][3]. Financially, the organization is robust, maintaining 33.6 months of working capital to ensure operational continuity [2].

baseline_narrative.headline: Zaytuna College serves as the first accredited Muslim liberal arts college in the United States, dedicated to grounding students in both Islamic and Western scholarly traditions.
strengths: High financial stability with 33.6 months of working capital
Strong fundraising efficiency of $0.11 per $1 raised
Accredited academic programs that integrate Islamic and liberal arts curricula
baseline_narrative.summary: Located in Berkeley, California, Zaytuna College offers specialized degree programs including a Bachelor of Arts in Liberal Arts and Islamic Studies and a Master of Arts in Islamic Texts [3][4]. The institution operates with a total revenue of $18,359,667 and maintains a commitment to educating morally committed intellectual and spiritual leaders [1][2].

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who view their giving as a long-term investment in American Muslim institutional infrastructure and value academic accreditation.
donor_motivations: Want to support the first accredited Muslim liberal arts college in the US
Value the synthesis of Islamic and Western intellectual traditions
Prefer supporting established institutions with high financial stability
Seek to fulfill zakat through higher education scholarships
giving_considerations: Donations contribute to a large endowment and significant cash reserves
Impact is measured in decades (leadership development) rather than immediate relief
Program efficiency is lower than emergency relief charities
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking immediate humanitarian impact or those who prefer charities with very low overhead and minimal reserves.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects verified academic accreditation and outcome tracking, though specific cost-per-student metrics are not public.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: Zaytuna creates impact by educating a new generation of Muslim scholars who can navigate both classical texts and modern contexts.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Accreditation ensures that the degrees provided have recognized value in the broader professional and academic world.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: While the college has high reserves, its <cite id="2">19.7% revenue growth</cite> indicates active expansion of its campus and programs.

strengths.detail: The college maintains <cite id="1">33.6 months of working capital</cite>, providing a massive buffer for long-term institutional growth.
Zaytuna spends only <cite id="1">$0.11 to raise every $1</cite>, significantly outperforming many non-profit benchmarks.
The institution is <cite id="4">accredited by the WASC Senior College and University Commission</cite>, ensuring academic rigor.

strengths_deep_dive: Zaytuna College's primary strength lies in its institutional maturity and fiscal health. With <cite id="2">total assets exceeding $50 million</cite> and a <cite id="2">3-year revenue CAGR of 19.7%</cite>, the college has transitioned from a startup to an established institution. Its <cite id="1">fundraising efficiency of $0.11 per $1 raised</cite> indicates a highly loyal donor base and effective development operations. Furthermore, its <cite id="3">accreditation status</cite> validates its unique curriculum, which integrates classical Islamic sciences with the liberal arts, a first for a Muslim institution in the West.
rich_narrative.summary: founded in 2009, Zaytuna College represents a landmark in American Muslim education as the <cite id="1">first accredited Muslim liberal arts college</cite> in the United States. Based in Berkeley, California, the institution seeks to bridge the gap between Islamic and Western scholarly traditions through its <cite id="3">BA in Liberal Arts and Islamic Studies</cite> and <cite id="4">MA in Islamic Texts</cite>. The college reported <cite id="2">total revenue of $18,359,667</cite> in 2023, primarily driven by <cite id="2">$15.2 million in contributions</cite>. While the institution maintains a <cite id="1">program expense ratio of 56.0%</cite>, which is lower than the peer median, it demonstrates exceptional fiscal sustainability with <cite id="1">33.6 months of working capital</cite> in reserve. This financial cushion allows the college to focus on its mission of preparing <cite id="3">morally committed intellectual and spiritual leaders</cite> without the immediate pressure of funding volatility. The college is <cite id="8">zakat-eligible</cite>, providing a unique avenue for Muslim donors to support higher education and institutional capacity building within the American Muslim community.
